text:
The aroma is coffee, some chocolate and caramel. Pours a dark brown with some amber hues. Light tan head mostly diminishing and good lacing. The taste is bitter. 
The body is medium/light, the texture creamy but a little thin. The carbonation lively and the finish bitter. Very coffee and not too bad of a beer.
C-. Pours a black color with khaki head. Its got a quite bitter aftertaste

St Paul, Mn - The Wine Thief & Ale Jail - 22 oz bomber, Black as tar pour with some purple accents, devoid of light coming through. Sticky, but thin mocha colored head. Aroma of faint coffee, some chocolate, and creosote, pleasant. Full bodied dry stout flavor. Some bakers unsweetened chocolate, day old black coffee and hints of pipe tobacco - finishes with some fresh topsoil. Thickish creamy mouthfeel. Overall, very decent stout.

Refrigerated brown bomber from FlandersNed poured into an English pint glass. Black with small beige head. Aroma is coffee, medium body, lower carbonation, and small-bubble lacing. Taste is big coffee, cola, some lactose, sone chocolate, and a little ash.  Bottle may have past its prime.

22 ounce bottle into snifter; no bottle dating, but is a recent release. Pours nearly opaque dark brown/black color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light khaki head with good good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big nutty medium roast coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, cream, brown sugar, toffee, and toasted dark bread; with light notes of smoke, dark fruit, herbal, and roast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt and coffee notes; with great strength. Taste of big nutty medium roast coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, cream, brown sugar, toffee, and toasted dark bread; with light notes of smoke, dark fruit, herbal, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/roast bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of nutty coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, cream, brown sugar, toffee, toasted dark bread, light smoke, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and coffee flavors; with a great roasted bitter/sweet balance, and zero acrid/astringent roasted flavors after the finish. Slight dryness from herbal/roast bitterness, lightly increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/silky, and slightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is awesome. Zero warming alcohol for 7.8%. Overall this is a fantastic imperial coffee stout! All around outstanding complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and coffee flavors; very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV. Awesome vibrant coffee character with great balanced malt complexity that is never overly roasty, bitter, or charred. Great showcase of the coffee. A highly enjoyable offering.
Tap at lyn 65. Black with very little off white head. as expected nose. Smooth. Very nice sweet coffee taste . Dark chocolate, heavy coffee taste. Well balanced and very good.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2016 A solid light tan head on a near black body. Nose features fresh coffee, cocoa and cream. A really we balanced IS, leading with fresh coffee, coffee grounds and cocoa.  This might be the most powerful presentation of coffee tastes in an IS that I have ever had.  With this taste I almost expect to be spitting out coffee grounds as I drink.  Solid touches of caramel and roasted malt, and hints of cherry add to the profile. Medium, to medium/thin body with a less rich mouth feel than expected. Taste thins out a bit too quick as well, but still a nice effort.

Pours black with a minimal khaki head. A robust aroma consists of heavy chocolate, along with coffee, roasted malts, and a little bit of caramel. The taste is still full of chocolate, specifically dark chocolate. Coffee, cocoa, and some caramel impressions are found underneath. Some roasted malty elements come through at the end. This one isnt all that sweet, though sweetness is noticeable. A short and sharp aftertaste is chocolate. Medium in body, with a thick texture, and and subtle carbonation is found. A solid stout all around.
Bottle. Aroma is slightly creamy coffee and mild earth. Tastes the same. Smooth and tasty. Slightly foamy carb gives a nice mouthfeel. Very good.
Dark black, no head. Strong acidic coffee flavors. Some cola. A nice coffee stout.
Bottle - pours dark brown tan head - nose/taste of coffee, chocolate, light roast black malt - medium body
Bottle. Pours black. Aroma and taste are largely coffee, some roasted malts and chocolate.

A fine coffee stout...not sweet but not bitter. Mild flavor with coffee forward. No standout attributes...it is what it is....and is a fine brew. I prefer a thicker mouthfeel but considering it is mid-summer Im fine with a thin pour and it is not watered...simply not thick.

Thanks Johnmay! (Great dude from WI and untapped buddy)
This was poured into a nonic.
The appearance was a dark brown color close to black with a one finger white to off white foamy head that dissipated within less than a minute. No lacing.
The smell took rich dark and milk chocolate to boot at roasty and sweet coffee bean (somewhat espresso-like). Light cake underneath.
The flavor takes the previously mentioned flavors to combine nicely. Lingering chocolate cake-like to cocoa rich aftertaste. Quick sweet wet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. Carbonation rides nicely along - slight stickiness, but acceptable.
Overall, really nicely done American stout with coffee and chocolate to boot, usually not one I do this time of year, but still well done!
Bottle shared by a friend. Pours darkest brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate and slight coffee. Malty and chocolatey flavor with a roasty coffee finish.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2016 Pours dark brown with a thin head, decent clingy lacing. Aroma is almost exclusively roast coffee, muted notes of malt exist as well. Taste is espresso, sweetened somewhat by the malt but with a mostly bitter, dry finish. Mouthfeel is light for a stout and somewhat thin. Id probably feel differently about this one if I loved black coffee; as it is its not a bad offering, but certainly not on par with the other CW stouts Ive had. This could be amazing if it aged for 6-12 months in a bourbon barrel before bottling. As is, its decidedly "meh."

22 oz. bottle thanks to Scott Stanley. Very deep brown color with slow receding head. Aroma is modest amounts of coffee beans, hints of char, caramel and coco powder.

The flavor is equal parts coffee and Chocolate nuances. Similar to a chocolate covered espresso bean. Decent amount of roasted malt backbone. The body leans of the full side with lots of lingering coffee. Coffee forward and delightful for the coffee lover in me. Still yet another quality made beer from this brewery.
Bottle thanks to Will. Pours a very dark brown with small tan head that lasts. The aroma is strong roast and chocolate. Medium mouth, strong coffee roast, cocoa, nice bitter finish, very good.

Deep mahogany pour with a brown head. The aroma of coffee hits you during the pour. Roasted goodness awaits my first sip. Taste is roasted malt and coffee. A little bitterness in the finish and in the aftertaste. Very tasty. A wonderful coffee stout. Just a tad bit of lacing.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2016 On tap at the Taphouse. Pours black with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a crisp coffee supported by roasted malts and a bit of dark grains. Flavor has roasted malts and coffee with a nice dark grain backbone.

Tap at The Tap House in Rochester, MN. Pours black, nice lacing as I drink it down. Aroma is coffee grounds, some bitter cocoa. Bitter overall. Sippable but fatiguing. Could be circumstances. Good beer though, tons of flavor and smooth.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma is roasty malt and coffee, a touch of dark fruit. Taste is roasty chocolate and coffee. A bit thin for the ABV, but really tasty.

Coffee, coffee, coffee is REALLY obvious after letting a bottle gather dust in the beer fridge for a few years. Lightweight stout body makes sense given the coffee addition, yet some malt sweetness comes through (although the coffees bitterness is fighting to hold it back). Certainly the lightest weight stout Ive had from the Central Waters lineup.

Black pour with tan head... Aroma of dark roasted malts, chocolate, fresh coffee... Flavor is dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans... Really enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black pour with a single finger, espresso colored head. Aroma is full of chocolate. Creamy mouth, velvety. Taste is full of coffee at the finish. Big time coffee bomb. Starts off like a mocha, then the coffee comes in and just crushes your palate. Very easy drinking though, if you like coffee.

Bomber into tulip. Minneapolis.

Pours very dark brown, basically black. Small rim of white head. 

Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate. Pretty coffee centric. 

Taste has a coffee bitterness with sweetness to balance. 

Body is medium. Mostly smooth. Longer finish.

Bomber. Mahogany with a beige head that mostly fades. Strong roasted coffee aroma with some light grinds, some malt and molasses with a bit of caramel, slightly sweet with a moderate carbonation and body, enjoyable with a roasted dry finish.

Dark brown pour with ruby highlights. Medium tight tan head.
Nice roasted bean aroma . Cocoa and dark chocolate. 
Flavour is nice dark roasted malt. Medium to light body. Some good coffee and chocolate balance. Light burnt malt bitterness in finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle. 
Aroma is coffee forward with a nice coffee character but not over the top. Some medium chocolate notes with some light roast and a faint fruitiness. Some light caramel notes. 
Pours dark brown, almost black with a medium sized, dark tan head that recedes quickly to the edges where it lingers for a bit. Medium light lacing and small legs. 
Flavor is moderately sweet with some nice chocolate and light dark caramel notes. Some moderate coffee notes that add a light nuttiness. Some light roast notes as well. Medium bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium to medium full bodied with a bit of stickiness in the finish and medium carbonation. Low, but present astringency with low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a pretty nice smaller coffee beer. Nice chocolate and coffee notes with good complexity and a lighter body. Pretty tasty lingering coffee notes.
So happy to see this stout back. Medium dark black body. Good frothy 1/2 inch head. Tons of coffee aroma. Rich full body stout with a good amount of coffee taste. One of my favorite coffee stouts.
coffee and lots of it...taste is good....smell is ok...pour is really dark....(#457)...
via Beer Buddy for iPhone

"courtesy pfoxyjohn...a light-medium bodied slightly dry stout. the coffee went from subtle at 49 degrees to prominent after 10 minutes. roasted malt, bittersweet coffee. nice...almost a standout. got to revisit - all about the coffee, especially the aroma. still quite nice and still a 4 (maybe higher if i have one for breakfast!)"

Bomber. Black with a foamy light brown head. Intense nutty light roasted coffee, cocoa powder, powdered sugar and malt powder. Has a dry sweetness of cocoa powder followed by the bitterness of coffee. Heavier syrupy feel with minimal carbonation.

Incredible stout from central waters. Nice flavor of coffee and chocolate. The smell of chocolate hits the nose. Easy to drink and had at home. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber pours a dark brown/black with a medium khaki head. Aroma reminds me of chocolate chip cookie dough, with mild molasses. Taste of upfront roasted coffee, into smooth chocolate. Pretty nice.
Notes of Chocolate, coffee, nuts, toast, and vanilla. Dark body with light smooth mouthfeel and an elegant caramel tan head

Bottle. The pour is dark. The aroma isn't big coffee, more malt. The taste is actually a mix of coffee and toffee. Big coffee in the aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pour opaque dark brown. Nose coffee roast and chocolate. Taste lots of dark roast coffee. Some chocolate. Even mild nut finish. Light mouth feel. Bitter roast finish.

Dark black poor small tan head with nice lacing. Rich sweet chocolates with a touch of cocoa bitterness in the finish. A good hit of coffee well roasted. Aroma is a bit lighter than the flavor and is slightly surprising. Some almost walnut like characters when it opens up. Very good.

Bottle: black body with dark brown edges & a khaki layer of foam that gets reduced to a collar pretty quickly. Aroma has notes of burnt coffee beans, mild char, light oil, & a solid amount of roasted malts. Taste is also full of coffee, though not as roasty or charred as the aroma may indicate. Light creamy aspect with hints of toffee covered raisins. Finish has a mildly sharp astringency with a lingering finish of coffee. Good stuff, but it doesnt quite reach the upper echelon of coffee beers.

Almost opaque, very dark brown, thin beige head. Freshly roasted coffee beans, a little vanilla, chocolate syrup, and toast. A bit sweet, but creamy and smooth. Soft carbonation and lingering black coffee in the finish. Almost no alcohol presence.
Bomber to snifter. Bitter coffee aroma. Mild sweetness. Loads of coffee flavor. Maybe a little chocolate. Smooth carbonation. Coffee in beer. Yup.
Aroma is coffee malts roast, appearance is black with kahki head, taste is all coffee, this is a great beer if you like coffee

09/20/13 trade from Jamil. Rich coffee and dark chocolate nib scent over a beauty of a black pour. Lighter medium bodied feel, slick. Big roasty coffee flavor that dissolves to a rich cocoa and coffee underbelly. Through and through a delicious coffee stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tastes like coffee, more on the taste, not much of a nose. Somewhat acidic.. somewhat thin, but it isnt an imperial.

Draft at TOF. Pours dark brown, some lacing. BIG coffee nose. Fresh roasted coffee with a squirt of chocolate. Taste follows. Chocolate, coffee soda (like a mix of chocolate coke and coffee cola beverages I used to drink on occasion in my pre-alcohol days). Coffee lingers, fair amount of sweetness with muted roast biter finish. Creamy texture, medium to full body, average carbonation. Overall: solid sweet coffee stout.
Bottle from chase, pours black with low head, nice coffee and roast with a light alcohol finish, nice brew!

Pours dark with creamy tan head. Nose is of strong coffee and almost some sweetness as if I added cream. Taste is off strong coffee but very well blended. Body is medium to heavy. Honestly, this beer is a home run for the style and you couldnt ask for much more. Great beer.
This has a strong coffee forward taste and a solid palate to support it. Aromatics are strong roasted medium coffee and an overall slight malt. Great brew!

Pours a deep black with at huge, creamy, tan head that has a TON of staying power. Aroma has a strong coffee nose with mild lactose-type sweetness to the nose. Flavor is fantastic! A strong but not overly acidic coffee flavor. Its mellowed out by a smooth roasted malt with a light sweetness maybe with a bit of lactose sweetness. Body is perfect - modest body with lots a mild amount of carbonation to add a bit to the feel but not thin it out at all. Overall one of the best coffee stouts I have had. I love my coffee with a bit of sugar and cream and this delivers that balance of coffee bitter/acid with a body and sweetness that a creamer/sugar would deliver in your morning coffee. Fantastic roast used for this beer as it goes down very smooth.

Bottle. Black with thin tan head. Aroma is coffee grounds. Taste adds some bitter chocolate. Sharp carb. Very tasty and balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks Zach! 

Decadent coffee aroma fills the room. Silky, delicate, yet retains a robust roasty base. 

Bitter espresso first up, turns roasty before hoppy-coffee bitterness again brings us home. Good stuff, yet can't compete with the aroma.
Figured this beer would be tons of coffee and it truely was. Aroma is acidic coffee. Flavor is just cold coffee. Not my thing.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2013 Dark dark brown color with tan head. Immediately noticed a strong coffee smell upon pouring. Reminds me of espresso, dark chocolate, mocha ice cream. Other aromas of toffee and malt. Nice roasted java coffee is the dominate flavor, with done roasted malt and other nuttiness. Definitely a coffee beer, but the stout backbone is strong and encompasses the coffee rather than just being a vehicle for it. Not as weak as other coffee stouts. Long finish. Full bodied and slightly oily. Some carbonation. This is a great stout.  More than just a one trick pony.
 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber from Tosa Wine. Pours chunky black with a brown head. Aroma has coffee and coffee grounds and expresso, and some caramel malt. Very nice! Taste is of coffee, and sweet caramel and bakers chocolate with plenty of roast. Medium to full bodied and more bitter than sweet. Could use a little aging? Was better cooler than at cellar temp. Nice aroma and flavor. Central Waters does their dark beers well!
Aroma is COFFEE, sweet, roasty, some chocolate. Rich coffee flavor with chocolate, roasty and sweet. Medium body. Soft and creamy, just barely bitter. Lovely.

Dark brown body with small fizzy head. Aroma is sweet, roasty, and loaded with coffee, some chocolate. Rich coffee flavor with chocolate, roasty and sweet. Medium body. Sweet and roasty. Moderate roasted bitter dry finish of medium to long duration. Soft and creamy. Great coffee stout.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Dark brown in color with an average sized off-white head. Aroma is of coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is of coffee, roasted malts and chocolate.

Tap at 1515 release. All-black, with a ring of tan head. Slightly viscous. Big day-old black coffee on the nose, just a touch of piney hop. Smooth mouthfeel, coffee and more coffee. This is great. Where do you get bottles?!

Deep brown/close to black with a small, thin, off-white head. Aroma is of ground coffee, roasted malts, and some slight chocolate sweetness. Flavor is much like the aroma but more subtle. Smooth mouth-feel with a bitter coffee finish.

Sampled at GABF 2012 with Andrew and Moreau. Pours a deep blackish brown body with thin brown head. Aroma is super rich, black espresso, strong roast and a hint of sweet vanilla. Mouthfeel is creamy and thick with notes of black coffee, rich roast, light sweet malts, rich vanilla and sugar. Nice!
Had this at the 2012 Great American Beer Fest in Denver, Colorado. Basically drinking a cup of black coffee, not much else.

Bottle: &nbsp Pours black, large foamy light brown head, nice lacing. &nbsp Big strong sweet coffee aroma. &nbsp No mistaking this one. &nbsp Nice semi-sweet, slightly hoppy, coffee and roasted malt flavor. &nbsp This one is really smooth and easy to drink. &nbsp Not too heavy, but it coats and sticks to the tongue rather nicely. &nbsp A little bitter hops and bakers chocolate on the backside. &nbsp This one I have had for a while and it really held up well. &Nbsp I am guessing maybe it smoothed out over the year or two I had it.

12 ounce bottle pours a very dark brown color with aromas of fresh brewed coffee.  Flavors are all coffee, with some roasted malt on the back end.  Light vanilla comes through towards the end, very subtle.  A great beer to start the morning for college football.

Bottle shared by Chaney. Thanks Brandon!

A: This coffee stout appears a very dark brown color, bordering on black.Atop the beer sits a nice looking beige head that hangs out for a while and leaves a bit of lacing on the glass.

S: Whoa! Coffee. I sure do appreciate my coffee, so this is already shaping up to be my kind of beer. The coffee scents are really fresh and inviting. Very nice.

T: A truly delicious beer. In addition to the gourmet coffee taste, notes of vanilla and roasted malt round out this beer quite nicely. Its slightly sweet, but this is counter-balanced very well by the natural bitterness of coffee.

M: Nice feel. I didnt realize that this was over 8% abv. I found no astringency or undesirable bitterness that can accompany such a coffee bomb.

D: Id have this for breakfast. Very impressive. I would trade for this.

Has this at the blue dog.

Appears deep dark brown with a smallish tan head but well maintained throughout. There is some lacing here and there. By tilting the glass this way and that I was able to rustle up some more foamy head and also to gage the attenuation which appears to be well carbonated.

The aroma is as one might expect: rich malts highly roasted, bittersweet chocolates and black coffee. The coffee aroma is the most pronouned, but aroma is also well balanced.

Taste is again what you might expect, highly roasted malts almost to the put of being burnt, rich bittersweet chocolate and coffee, rich black coffee. Hints of nuts and molasses too can be tasted.

A thick bodied beer here with a hint of creaminess before turning slightly dry. Towards the end soft alcohol warming is present.

31st October 2009Post Borefts I Invasion of Fonefan and Charlottes room tasting! Dark brown beer. Light soft palate, rich coffee, not too bitter. A little chocolate in there. Finishes semi dry and with a little minerals. Very drinkable coffee stout.
Draft. Black pour with tan head. Roasted malt light coffee aroma tones. Flavor is fuller coffee, roasted, and light nutty tones.

12oz Bottle.  Rather thin pour with a short lived head.  Nose is heavy coffee and medium on the roasted malt side.  Taste is also heavy coffee but not much coffee bitterness.  The usual roasted malts, and faint chocolate also make their presence known.  Thin on the palate for a stout but very enjoyable overall.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Originally reviewed: 12/20/09. Poured into a standard pint glass. Pours a murky blackish-brown with some ruby tints on the edges. Small capper on the top. Left some sticky lace on the glass. Huge coffee scents waft out. Fresh ground coffee beans, big roasted tones, and hints of light vanilla. 

Nice creamy smooth beer. Moderate amount of carbonation; complements the style well. Not too filling at all. Nice bitter coffee flavor that finishes sweet and creamy. Mild hop bitterness. If coffee stouts are your thing, youd be hard-pressed to find a better option out there. Wow. What a great beer.

Draught at TJs:  Aroma of coffee, roasting, cream, and just a great cup of Joe.  Poured very deep amber/brown in color with a tiny tan head around the edges only.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of coffee, malt, roasting, cream, roasting, and my perfect cup of coffee.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, roast, cream, coffee finish is medium sweet, and medium bitter.  8.2%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  Joe brought it.  Lots of red in this and it is more opaque than most.  A decent tan head.  A sweet fruity nose.  Candy cherries.  Then some chocolate is smelled.  The flavor is coffee and chocolate.  Fruit is lighter than the aroma.  Some hops are tasted.  Not bad at all.

Uh oh, serious goobers floating about - looks like a goddamn blizzard in there... great color and head though, a bit more clarity than one might expect (if it was as dark as most of its peers I probably wouldnt have noticed all these little sons a bitches dog paddling around in my beer!)

Smells real nice, vanilla, caramel, instant coffee, cream.

Turned from coffee to caramel latte, very pleasant, bit of nutmeg maybe, vanilla, coffee grinds.
Too thin, really the downfall of this beer - lacking carbonation but there really is no need for it.

Overall, Im glad I put a year on one of these, the coffee really evolved without getting bitter or becoming muted - just goes to show that you might not have to follow every little rule to have fun cellaring beer.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Rich, solid black body with a large frothy khaki head. Nice retention keeps the head up before forming a nice, substantial skim. Fairly impressive lacing for the style.

S: Mellow roasted coffee. Smooth and subtle. Not burnt or charred. Some sweet caramel and chocolate in the background.

T: Compared to the nose, there is much more offered here. I really enjoyed the mellowness of the roasted coffee. Some stouts in this style have a potent coffee blast that masks all other flavors. Not so here. A rich, creamy sweetness of other roasted malts impart a delicate chocolate and caramel flavor.

M: Smooth, medium bodied. Moderate carbonation maintains the delivery from start to finish. Nice, delicate finish.

O: I cant say enough about the mellow complexity of this offering. It was a pleasant, easy to enjoy experience and is completely deserving of the praise it gets. Just dont expect an all out coffee assault.
Draught at Monks Cafe in Philadelphia. Nose and flavor hold espresso, roasted coffee bean and grounds, dark chocolate. Palate is light and drinkable. Good stuff!

Bottled, served in pint glass.

Dark brown with a lingering thick, cream-colored head that left nice lacing on the glass.

Has a unsurprisingly coffee-y, malty aroma.

Taste is slightly sweet with lots of coffee, some chocolate. Minimal hop presence. Bitter finish. Doesnt taste boozy at all.

Creamy mouthfeel.

I dont think I could ask for anything else in a coffee stout. Easily in my top three of Central Waters offerings.

The few Central Waters beers Ive had have been really nice, so while I did enjoy this beer, I just didnt feel like it did anything for me. The beer pours out a dark brown/black body with dark brown edges and a light, light tan 1/4" head. Aroma starts out with some coffee grounds, walnuts, light vanilla and some wet dirt. It was all really restrained though, as the volume was kept down to 4 instead of blaring at 9 or 10. Flavor had some astringent puckery character that I found a bit off putting, like putting a spoon of coffee and aspirin together. Coffee did show up, but when a brewery calls a beer a "coffee stout", in my opinion, it has to showcase coffee in the best way possible. I just didnt think this beer did that, as the coffee was too restrained for my liking. I have 4 more beers to change my opinion though. 

Re-rate 10/15/2011 

Keeping things pretty much the same. Its not getting any better in any way, but the aroma did change somewhat. What comes out is a Tabasco-like aroma...almost bell-pepper like. It wasnt bad, and some would probably be off-put by the aroma. I just found it interesting. The coffee level was still very restrained. No way is this an top-notch stout, but drinkable.

Black with a small tan head, no real retention, some lacing... very creamy coffee aroma, kinda one dimensional, lightly roasty... creamy coffee lightly roasty again on dimensional... medium body, oily mouthfeel...

Pours deep brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma has lots of light coffee aroma...hint of roasty malts.  Flavor is much more aggressive with the coffee but very tasty...subtle cocoa flavor as well.  Mouthfeel is lively...not too heavy...and the finish has roasty coffee and some cocoa.  They nailed what they were goin for here flavorwise.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 Dark brown.  Nutty roast coffee with a splash of cream and toasted malts.  Rounded coffee with a touch of acidity, roasted/toasted malt, light cream/sugar.  Finishes with lingering fresh roast.  Light, but without body.  Very easy to drink. Re-rate: 2015 bomber.  Real deal coffee beer.  Top notch diner coffee flavor. +1

It pours dark french press coffee in color with a small tan head. The aroma has hints of coffee and sweet malts, not enough especially if too cold. The flavor of subtley sweet coffee notes are present that end with some palatable bitterness.

Bottled. A red-brown beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes fo malt, caramel, and cold coffee. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and cold coffee, as well as lighter notes of alcohol, leading to a dry, roasted, and coffee like finish.
Bottle courtesy mlunger12: Poured a chocolate thick color with a off white to tan head. The aroma is coffee bean and dark chocolate. Taste is head on roasted coffee.

On tap at GTMW 2011, pours a very dark brown with a nice light brown head and some lacing, aroma was full of coffee and chocolate with some toffee, the flavor was pretty straight forward with notes of coffee and a chocolate finish, not bad.

Bottle - thanks SpencerDB.  Medium depth brown with a thin tan head.  Smells like fresh coffee and just a slight hint of mocha.  Taste is more fresh coffee, now the roastiness comes through.  Just a little bit of chocolate malt, but the big player is the coffee.  Strong and fresh, but not overwhelming.  I like it.

12oz bottled in October 2010.  Served at 60F.  A bit old for a coffee stout but lets see how this holds up.
Pours dark brown with a large tan head that leaves nice webs of lacing and holds a creamy cap.

Aroma is a nice blend of premium coffee beans, cocoa, vanilla and caramel.  Some nuts, bread and toast as well.  Smells like a coffee ice cream sundae topped with fudge, caramel and nuts.  Very inviting and very good strength.

Flavor pretty much follows suit.  Coffee ice cream sundae with plenty of delicious toppings.  Premium coffee, milk chocolate/cocoa, caramel, vanilla, some roasted malts, nuts and bread.  Some sweetness, low bitterness.  Minimal alcohol.  As it warms/progresses, the chocolate, caramel, etc step back a bit and becomes more straight up coffee and roasted malts.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, soft and creamy with low to moderate carbonation.

Well the coffee is still holding on strong and this is quite the treat.  Literally a dessert in a glass.  I could only imagine what a fresh sample would be like.  Also, the coffee used reminds me a lot of the coffee in Terrapins W-n-B which is one of my favorites.  Nice one!

Bottle aquired via trade. Dark brown pour with an inch and a half of tan foam and a surprising amount of spidery lacing. The nose on this is massive espresso backed by much lower amounts of chocolate and vanilla. Coffee dominates the flavor as well, I would actually say this is one of the most coffee dominant beers Ive ever had. Still some chocolate in there as well, but its less apparent. Slightly harsh and bitter mouthfeel, but not too bad. I liked this one a lot.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a beige head. Aroma shows notes of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, and a light herbal quality. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of vanilla and oak. Overall body is moderate, dry and significantly roasted.

Aroma: caramel, bread, cereal, chocolate, coffee, toast, roasty, vanilla, 
Appearennce: black, brown, frothy, tan foam, 
Taste: medium/light sweetness, lightly bitter, umami, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, slick feel, lively, long finish,  
Overall: Well done. A great beer. Definitely worth seeking out!

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2011 Bottle (thanks to theguy)...  Poured dark brown with amber highlights. Nose had coffee and some roast. Flavor had loads of coffee flavors.  Some roast, hazelnut flavors.  Strong French press coffee flavors with sweetener, oak, and a little bit of acidity.

Pours obsidian dark black. Large light brown fluffy head with thick creamy lacing. Long retention of both on the tulip glass. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee grind, mocha, milk chocolate, flowery hops. Taste is around the same with Italian espresso being the strongest followed up by dark fudge brownies, toffee, and a little bit of hop pine in the finish. This was a nice energy jolt of a beer to start with. One of the best coffee flavored beers I have had. Cheers

thanks hbmason for setting up a killer trade with madvike12oz bottle-pours a thin light brown head and brown/copper color.  Aroma is coffee/roasty-medium/dark malt, some earthy.  Taste is coffee/ashy/roasty-medium/dark malt, secondary biting earthy hops.

Poured into a pint glass. Big thanks to LusciousJackson for this treat.

4.5 A: Black color. Two fingers of creamy, tan head with good retention (excellent for a coffee beer) and tons of lacing (impressive for a coffee beer).

5.0 S: This is incredibly nutty. Im shocked at how nutty it is. After that there is a huge helping of milk chocolate and caramel. Only after that does the coffee come in. It mixes with the chocolate to give a cafe mocha vibe. Just a touch of roastiness to balance things out. This has a huge nose which is stronger than most beers twice the ABV.

5.0 T: The taste is much like the nose. Tons of nuts, milk chocolate, and caramel. Coffee complements rather than dominates. The coffee and roasted malts team up to give only a mild roastiness. This is a fairly sweet beer overall. Perhaps a touch of dark fruitiness, but that all falls to the wayside.

5.0 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Incredibly creamy and super smooth.

5.0 D: Im a pretty harsh rater and Ive searched and searched for a reason to not give this beer the scores that I have. Obviously, I could not find any reasons. This is easily the best single stout Ive had. Incredible amount of flavor and each component contributes positively to the whole. Time for an ISO.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-03-2011 19:10:13

Bottle shared by jcwattsruger, thanks John. Poured a dark brown body with a smaller dark beige foamy bubbly head. Aroma is loaded with coffee, cream.....sort of like walking into a coffee shop but its not like I go into many of them because I only like coffee in my beer. Flavor of coffee, cream and toast. Medium bodied with a slightly milky feel, average to smaller head with bubbly carbonation. Probably the beer of the night at this tasting.

On tap at Capones, Norristown. Deep, oily black pour with a thin cappucino head. Nose is richly malty with strong, ripe, roasted bean and some dry chocolate and hops. But is full, smooth, and creamy. Dry and bitter flavors contrast quite appealingly with the deep chocolate and rich malts, hitting on most every point for the style. Quite enjoyable.

Bottle shared with John. Thanks JC. Pours out a dark brown color with a small off white head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malts, and light sweetness. Taste is a nice balance of roasted malts, coffee and a very slight sweetness in there also. Very solid, with a nice coffee flavor.

12 oz bottle.  Ebony with a slim beige head.  Nose is coffee, cocoa and a touch of molasses.  Medium body with a buzz.  Palate coating with residual coffee acidity.  Taste is coffee, molasses and earthy brown sugar.  Finishes with Bakers chocolate, hay and grass.
Sampled at DLD 2011. Rather light for a stout, kind of brown. Sudsy porter head. A nice sweet coffee smell. Quite sweet taste, more of a coffee cordial. Goes down very nicely.

Delicious aroma of brownies and coffee. Color is dark brown with a quickly diminishing off-white head. Tastes sweet and finishes bitter: flavors of coffee, chocolate, and corn cereal are followed by piney, resinous hops. Very tasty beer. Would go great with breakfast or as a desert beer.

12oz bottle. Dark brown pour, with a thin brown head. Slightly thick pour with a tad bit of lacing left behind. Aroma has a good bit of coffee notes to it, along with chocolate and malt,  but it wasnt super intense by any means. Flavor was a little bit on the bitter side with a nice sweet finish. It was an enjoyable coffee stout but I would have liked the coffee to come out a little bit more in the aroma and flavor.  Maybe jazz it up with some vanilla.
Nearly black. Brown head.  Load of coffee in the nose and flavor.  Nice black coffee and a light tartness.  Good stuff.

Deep brown/Black pour beige sticky head sticky lacing .... aroma of fresh roasted coffee and chocolate ..... taste is of bitter chocolate, coffee, fresh roasted and smooth mouthfeel, rich caramel malt ... dry roasted light bitter finish. Not a bad coffee stout

Draft at Capones.  Pours deep blacksih, turbid, with off-tan head.  Nose is dark malt, cacao, heavy coffee.  Tastes dark malty, with a pronounced coffee flavor, but the good kind of coffee, not the day old coffee grounds that emerge in some coffee brews.  The coffee is at the forefront here, but the malt and cacao match is well.  Well done.

12 oz bottle from Casanova (Hudson, WI). Pours a dark opaque brown hue, maybe some blackish color, but largely dark bitter cocoa brown, with a moderate tannish beige hue that cakes at a decent level, laces a-ok. Aromas are a moderate blast of coffee grounds, cold coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, some caramel, biscuits, and toast. Coffee seems the dominant factor. Initial is medium bodied, a bit heavier with strong coffee and mocha, some sweeter cocoa moves into the fold with toffee, caramel, biscuits, toast. The cocoa and coffee stick to the palate, inviting, not overbearing providing a pretty good clash of dry roast and sweet malts. Some cookies, toffee and a strong coffee presence, raw roastiness with supporting chocolate, cocoa coming in behind. Finish leaves roasty toasty malts and coffee largely, some sweetness to temper. I liked this. Its not the most complex coffee, but its a tasty beer that works. Pretty good coffee stout.

Bottle: Poured hazy deep brown color stout with a nice foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of dry and aromatic coffee with nice roasted malt with slight bitter aftertaste. Taste is also a nice mix with some quite dry bitter note of coffee with some aromatic notes of coffee and light roasted malt.  Body is a bit light with great carbonation. Well brewed and easily drinkable without too much complexity.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 3/18/11. 12oz bottle courtesy mlunger12. Opaque black pour with a small tan head. Huge coffee aroma with a hint of milk chocolate. Mild stout flavor with roast and a hint of sour, coupled with some coffee and chocolate. Not bad. 7 3 7 3 14 = 3.4
Re-rate. On tap at the Great Taste of the Midwest. Huge coffee aroma and flavor with a small touch of chocolate in there as well. Very nice. Upping the rating!

12oz bottle into my Rochefort glass...Boring pour, light tan head no retention or lacing. The beer is very light colored for a stout, medium brown pretty clear...Aroma is a total one noter, all light smooth coffee. Its a really nice coffee smell but lacks complexity...The taste is the same as aroma, all coffee but again its light, smooth and incredible easy to drink. Just wish there was something else here but coffee. 

Ovearll, a very good easy drinking coffee stout. To be great needs to add a little complexity, something besides coffee.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown color, nearly opaque, with minimal garnet light shining through. The head was tall and tan with good retention. Smelled of toffee, roasted nuts, and dark chocolate. Surprisingly, it also smelled a bit like chili peppers and shoe leather. Medium bodied and sweet. Cocoa, subduded roastiness (from the coffee I guess), toffee. Not much coffee, really, but seemingly a fair bit of alcohol. So so.

12oz bottle shared with the tallahassee crew. Pours dark with very little head, aroma... Coffee, lots of coffee. Great roasty coffee taste, this is delicious. Almost more of a sweet stout than a regular stout. Quite nice.
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear dark brown - white head. Coffee, roasted, chocolate, light chili sharpness, ryebread, candy notes. Pleasant.

Bottle at Papsø.
Hazy red brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel and coffee.
Roasted flavour if caramel, dark chocolate and coffee.
Roasted finish of coffee.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark amber and hazy with a small tan head. Aroma is coffee and slight herbal. Sweet toffee caramelish, slight liqourice, roasted breadish and distinct coffee herbal. Ends dry and herbal finish.

cloudy dark brow,, smooth white head.
strong coffee aroma, roasted stuff. dusty.
flavor is coffee, caramel,roasted stuff ,dusty notes, chocolate,

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Doodler. Pours an orangey brown with a slight haze and a beige head. Very dry coffee aroma with an almost chili-like driness. Medium body, some sweet roast and vanilla with notes of sweet coffee. A little malt astringency. Nice. 150311

12 oz bottle.

It pours a deep dark brown with a foamy light tan head. It doesnt look as good as th Peruvian Morning.

The aroma is top-notch though, absolutely. It smells like a coffee house in the area surrounding the bottle, it is super-fragrant. If you sniff from the bottle you get a thick hit of caramel. From the glass it is kind of because there is a hint of metallic scent. For this i have to dock it a little. Sniff th bottle, you will enjoy it more than our of the glass, which I find interesting.

The flavor is also coffee to the full, but again Im getting the metallic character. It is a bit too coffee-oriented for me, it pretty much tastes like metallic coffee. I prefer their Peruvian Morning so much more.

I know this is a coffee stout and i dont like coffee, but that hasnt held me back from loving other coffee infused beers, but this is for coffee lovers only.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-04-2010 00:40:31

Pours a nice big 2 finger beige head. Body is an extremely dark brown. Head retention was above average and lacing was good.

Aroma is of roasted coffee and chocolate/caramel malts. There is a nice contrast of burnt/charred coffee and sweet dark chocolate. Hops are slightly present and alcohol is almost undetected.

Taste is bitter strong coffee at first. The malt comes through next with some bakers chocolate and smoked malts. Hops are in the background and the bitterness is amplified by the coffee. For over 8% alcohol,  I could barely taste any booze. 

Mouthfeel is nice and medium bodied. Carbonation levels are somewhat high and lighten up the beer some more. Head did thicken up the beer a little and give it some nice stout creaminess, finished abit dry though

Overall beer was pretty good. Got a 12 oz bottle in a trade and went through it very easily. Alcohol was masked nicely. The only drawback to the beer was that it was abit too coffee heavy. I love coffee stouts, they are my favorite style but I think this one needed something extra to balance it out. Unfortunately this beer doesnt make it to colorado but if you see it in your neck of the woods, definitely pick some up, very delicious stout.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is predominantly coffee, more of a lighter roast being showcased than the usual dark roast prevalent in other coffee stouts.  There is also something off about the aroma, and I believe it stems from the high alcohol clashing with the coffee.  Little bit of maple syrup and some peanut butter as well.  Vanilla shows up in a big way with further warming.  The smell is growing on me, and it would be great if the alcohol was toned down.  The flavor is equally as good, with plenty of even roasted coffee, peanut butter, and roasted malt.  Lightly salty and a little chalky in the finish.  Finish lingers with a lot of roast and a slight alcohol burn.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is a touch high.  Overall, this is a surprisingly good coffee stout.

Tasted on 2/9/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Discount Liquors in Milwaukee.  Pours an opaque dark brown with an average off-white head that slowly recedes to thin but even lace.  The nose is earthy and somewhat herbaceous coffee with tons of roasted malt, milk chocolate, and a bit of bitterness as well.  The flavor is lightly sweet milk chocolate and molasses up front, moving to the more roasted and bitter notes of coffee and dark chocolate, and more chocolate and light fruitiness on the back.  The body is very thick with average carbonation and a long bitter coffee and chocolate finish.

Traded bottle side-by-side with the bourbon barrel brother. Man I really liked this. Appearance was dark black with a thin khaki ring around the edge. Great aroma of coffee, vanilla and sugar. Flavor was smooth cold coffee. Just a hint of bitterness that does not linger. Creamy mouthfeel. Tasty!

Bottle. Pour is reddish brown which then appears black when in glass and has a nice kahki head that fades to a collar around glass. Aroma is fresh brewed coffee and roasted malt. Taste is bitter strong coffee with a roasted malt that lingers. Palate is somewhat thin, but leaves a nice chaulky dry feel. I really like this and would be blown away if I got a creamy thicker version of this.

Pours an opaque chocolate brown with thick frothy dark tan head which does dissipate. Aroma is extremely nutty-reminiscent of roasted chestnuts. Also present is an aroma of espresso and dark chocolate mixed with a bit of almond and vanilla. Flavor has definite notes of coffee and bittersweet chocolate with almond undertones. Body is creamy and thick yet not syrupy. A very delicious beer.

Bottle.  Deep brown in color with a small, quickly fading, off white head.  Aroma is dominated by roasted coffee with some chocolate.  Flavor is more coffee, cream, with chocolate in the finish.  Good, drinkable, simple coffee stout.

12 oz. bottle poured to a small snifter for a cellar tasting at Lunar brewing Co.. The color was dark brown, and the head was a modest amount of tan foam, with spotty lacing. The aroma was roasty espresso and light malt smoothness. The flavor added light brown sugar sweetness and low hop bitterness. Lacked some body, but a decent coffee Stout nonetheless.

Thanks bauermj. Pours a dark tan allowing significant light with one finger of yellowish tan head. Nose is mildly grainy with bakers chocolate and sweet coffee. Flavor is predominated by coffee with notes of bakers chocolate and grain. So basically the aroma re-worded. Palate has a gain acidity with a mouthfeel that could be fuller.

From notes:

Bomber received as an extra in a trade with ThomasHardy. Thanks again man!

Pours a very dark chocolate/chestnut brown color with slight mahogany edges when held to a light source and a thin one finger foam head that quickly settles into a thin ring. Sporadic spots of lacing left behind.

Strong roasted coffee/espresso bean aroma with a nice silky chocolate malt presence in the nose. Slightly smokey smelling with hints of caramel, toffee, oatmeal and tootsie roll. Complex nose but a bt overwhelmed by the overly roasted coffee presence.

Medium bodied with a huge roasted coffee/espresso bean flavor. Im also picking up some silky lactic chocolate notes as well as some hazelnut, oatmeal, toffee and caramel. Slightly acrid with a dry bitter finish.A bit unbalanced with a too strong of a coffee presence for my taste.

Bottle, thanks to an off-site co-worker bringing it into town. Poured a brown color with a off-white head. A little more translucent than I expected, but thats not a bad thing. Flavor is nice notes of coffee, toasted malts, toffee, touch of chocolates.

Bottle from zimmerbloke.  Dark brown pour, a thin head slowly takes shape on top.  The aroma shows roasted oats, dark chocolate, and some espresso beans.  This is a nice tasting Stout.  Fuller than expected and well-rounded.  Creamy palate with a touch of roasty bitterness towards the finish and is a nice compliment to the softer flavors.  Good mocha flavor, some slick caramel, and oats too.  Easy to drink.  This is good stuff.

Brown color/ fleeting head. Chocolate syrup, coffee, dark roast aromas. medium bodied. Good chocolate, mocha sweet coffee flavors with a burnt malt bitterness to balance. Thanks jason for this bottle!
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Bottle pours almost black with thin tan head.  Very nice coffee aroma.  taste roasted malts and coffee.  Finish prolonged with slightly bitter roast, not bad at all.  Palate a little on thin side and carbonated.  Alcohol disguised.
I ended up giving it a decent score but was hoping for better.  Pretty good but there are better coffee stouts out there.

Brewhouse Coffee Stout, 12oz bottle poured into sam smith english pint glass.  Currently ranked #1 American Stout on BA.   Pours dark brown, I can actually see through it when holding it up.  Appearance is almost cola like, lots of carbonation with a small bubbly beige head.  A hard pour on my second bottle created a much larger and more appealing head.  Nose is coffee, chocolate, vanilla and sweet milk.  Taste is complex, very heavy on the chocolate with a roasted coffee middle but almost no harshness or bitterness in the finish.  As it warms the roasted coffee becomes more dominate.  Taste more molasses and vanilla and the finish becomes slightly bitter.  Very enjoyable beer but in my opinion is more like a brown ale than a stout.  I really want to crack open a November right now and compare.  Very similar but this has more of a roasted coffee flavor.  Doesnt taste like 8.2%, but it is starting to feel like it is.  More drinkable than you would expect and more than some similar 6% offerings.  I still think this is a american brown ale and am going to rate it as such.  Otherwise I wouldnt give it as high of a score as the beer deserves.

12 ounce bottle poured into snifter. Beer is dark brown with slight head. Carbonation appears to be low.  Taste of chocolate, coffee, mild roast & sweet.  Has a smooth & creamy mouthfeel. Medium bodied with some minimal sweetness.  A bitter ending that finishes a little dry.  A very awesome beer that goes great with dessert.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 Was lucky enough to pick up a bottle of this at Steves in Madison, WI in August 2009.

Pours a dark brown with an espresso head. The nose is overwhelming coffee and dark malts, and this is exactly how the taste follows it up. The true highlight of this beer is the mouthfeel--its so utterly thick and creamy that its unlike most other coffee stouts. This has the mouthfeel of a Russian Imperial, and I really wish that I could give this a 5.5 for MF and that other brewers would follow. Drinkability is way up there as well, as the creamy mouthfeel makes you want sip after sip.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

from Sonomas....smooth coffee nose and flavor; dark but not quite black color with thin tanish head; medium coffee based taste...very smooth; creamy soft palate with lingering finish...great lighter stout for those chilly winter evenings...a winner for Central Waters and cheese lovers everywhere.

12oz bottle pours a nearly opaque, but not quite black, deep brown with a creamy, off white head.  Coffee nose, dusty, nutty, lightly sweet.  Flavor is heavy coffee, nutty, brown sugar, lightly malty, tinge of bitterness.  Medium bodied, dry finish.

12oz bottle from a buddy that works with me. Poured a nice oily dark brown color with tan head. Scents of fresh brewed coffee and chocolate. Taste is light rosted coffee, thin mouth feel and mellow finish. Pretty good.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2011 Bottle at Bodega in La Crosse. This beer is a not quite opaque brown color with amber around the edges. Medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Roasted coffee and malt aroma. Medium body with a roasted coffee character along with flavors of chocolate and nuts. The finish is espresso with a dark chocolate aftertaste. Solid from start to finish.

Single Bottle from Downer Wine and Spirits.  Pours a jet black with the thin white head.  Aroma is very roasty, very coffee.  A little bitter on the pallate drive again by the coffee.  Carbonation feels just right.  Flavor is all coffee.  Another fine brew from Central Waters.

Poured a very dark, brown-cola color.  Nice creamy lace after the small head faded.  Aroma was primarily of coffee with hints of the malts beneath.  Taste starts out with coffee and then into the local malts.  If finishes with a moderately strong hop finish.  Coffee after-taste is left.  Mouth feel is very nice - good density.  Its almost like a meal in itself.  Overall, probably the best coffee stout I have drank thus far.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: 12oz bottle courtesy of maximum12. thanks, corey! pours a dark, cola-brown with a thin, bubbly, beige head and a nice ring of lace. aroma is very nice with fresh, roasted coffee, milk chocolate, cream, and dark malts with hints of vanilla. flavor is great with smooth, creamy, coffee, dark chocolate, and light ash with hints of cinnamon, nuts, and a touch of black cherry ahead of the charred, espresso finish. palate is medium bodied and slick on the tongue with solid carbonation. overall, a damn nice coffee stout.
12 ounce bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a pure black hue with a small white head. The aroma is massive milky coffee. A sweet heavily roasted coffee flavor, sweet sugary and smooth. A nice coffee brew.

Bottle. Pours a nice dark brown color with a nice coastered 1/2 finger head. Pretty solid aroma of coffee and dark chocolate with some vanilla. Creamly medium mouthfeel. Nice and smooth coffee flavor that ends a little bitter like drinking straight light roast coffee. Some alcohol notes in the taste as well. Not quite the best coffee stout I have had before but certainly not the worst either. Good lace left on the glass.
bottle on RBSG10 bus - dark brown pour, medium thick tan head. Decent... dark chocolate biter, earthy coffee grinds, medium-thin mouthfeel.

A: pours a nice dark rich brown, practically brown. lightly creamed coffee colored head with a low retention rate and nice light lacing.

S: wonderful roasted malt aroma, dark chocolate, huge roasted coffee notes. light sweetness of cherries.

T: outstanding flavor. big roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, like a mocha coffee drink with some espresso. wonderful balance with the hops. great coffee notes here with the fair trade coffee. aftertaste is pure coffee and chocolate.

M: full bodied, but not too thick. mild carbonation level. amazing palate. extremely smooth.

D: outstanding brew. great flavored stout. this shouldnt be a want once, this is an amazing beer that should be in my house permanently. If only they would come to Florida, life would be better.

Dark brown pour, aromas of dark coffee roast, esspresso, some light chocolate and a bit of sweet cream.  Mouthfeel is creamy.  The flavor consists of bitter bakers chocolate, cream, and bitter coffee ground.  Simple, but wonderfully flavorful coffee stout

Bottle on the bus during RBSG between Dark Horse and Bells.  Pours a lightly hazed brown with a medium sized beige head.  Soft coffee on the nose.  Nice coffee and light chocolate flavors.  A little toast.  Finishes with more toast, roast, and chocolate and coffee.

A-pours a black liquid, virtually opaque, with a dense creamy tan colored head.

S-the smell is quite nice, lots of roasted coffee, very refined nose, notes of milk chocolate and some roasted malts.

T-the flavors are huge, pretty much the same as the nose.  the coffee seems a little more roasted or even slightly burnt.  some creamy milk chocolate in there as well with a light coffee bitterness in the back.

M-smooth, creamy medium to full body, moderate carbonation, slick on the back of the throat.

D-pretty straight forward, lots of coffee, the taste seemed a little burnt but still pretty enjoyable.
Sampled at a Tampa crew weekly tasting on 08-03-10. Bold coffee and molasses nose. Bitter chocolate, roasted malt and coffee afterwards. A little fizzy.

Pours a deep reddish brown color, pretty gosh darned light for a stout. The head is that ole classic espresso swirl. The aroma has plenty enough diner coffee both very roasty and rich with dark chocolate notes. The flavor is a lot of awesome chocolate on coffee with plenty of bitter notes both in the coffee and dark chocolate ways respectively. I reckon this drank pretty good.

Bottle, poured by someone on the RBSG bus. Pours pale brown, thin pale tan head, good lacing. Nose is coffee, chocolate, cream, toast, a bit light, but pleasant. Flavours of soy, chocolate, coffee, sticky finish. Pleasant, but it doesnt really jive with my palate.
Thanks to someone on the RBSG bus! A little astringent. Nice grainy coffee. Chocolate flavor and finish is awesome.
22 oz. bottle,  Dark black with nice head and lacing.  Great coffee taste, Central Waters did a great job with this one.  I will definitely be seeking out again.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle. HUGE coffee on the nose and taste. Brown pour with a tan head. Dominate feature is coffee - absolutely awesome. Easy drinking as well.
It tastes something like coffee, but its not quite coffee is it? This flavor is a mystery to me, real good though, anyways. Recommended wholeheartedly.

Thanks Brian23456 for hooking me up with this! 12 oz bottle.

A- Body is a dark, murky, nearly opaque maple brown hue. Body consistency is surprisingly dynamic. Pours with a frothy 2 finger creme brulee colored head that slowly fades to 1/2 finger and leaves a ton of lacing behind in the glass.

S- Nose is good- and very rich, dark chocolate, toffee, a lot of caramel, and of course some roasted malt in the background.

T-Flavor is also good and rich-not as sweet and thick as the nose gives the impression of though. Upfront is some toffee, roasted malt, a hint of earthy hop, and a hint of chocolate and caramel. The highlight of the finish is roasted malt but there are nice accents of sweet caramel, chocolate, toffee, and molasses to balance it as well as a faint impression of herbal hops. What lingers on the palate is a moderate roasted malt bitterness as well as impressions of the rest of the palate.

P-High tingly carbonation and a relatively thick, smooth, body.

O- This is a good, drinkable, American Coffee stout. Great balance of sweet and black coffee notes. This brew is certainly a coffee stout-but is more well put together and less extreme than a lot of examples that I have had of this sub-style. It is deserving to be ranked among the best for the style. Also a pretty big flavor for a non-imperial ABV.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-17-2010 17:03:23

Served from a 12 oz bottle via trade with klikger (BA), The appearance is rich dark coffee brown with a small lighter brown head. The aromas are pure with French pressed coffee with a sweet floral spice in the middle. The flavors are as coffee as the nose, although the flavors pull me in a different coffee direction then the nose. A lot of medium roasted malts spreads out the coffee. The mouth has a medium carbonation, and a medium full body. Very enjoyable beer if you are a coffee lover like me.

Oh yeah, this beer is that good. So impressive. Poured a coffee brown and a small head that retreated to a thin ring. I realy have to give it to this beer in the Aroma category- WOW. Huge coffee with accents of sweet malt and dark chocolate. The taste is as well fantastic and gives you big coffee, toast malt, chocolates and here and there a bit of grape hard candy- but the the last doesnt surface in every sip. Body is very nice and the palate, though dominated by coffee, is still fairly complex. Im also in love with Peruvian Morning, so adequate praise must be given to the Emy Js coffee used in both of these stouts. Well done CWBC.

Pours a dark brown color with a nice creamy tan color head. First thing I noticed was a great coffee aroma just pounding my nose. There is also some hints of roasted malts and alcohol buried in there as well. Flavor is of fantastic coffee bean that turns into a sweet malt bitterness.The body is a medium build. Great coffee aftertaste. Thanks BBL!!
(12oz bottle, courtesy of  Cavie)  Pours an amber-brown body with small beige head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, nuts, and cocoa.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep brown body with a thin, brown head that dissipates immediately and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is rich dark chocolates and a good amount of fresh coffee. Some brown sugar, hazelnut, caramel, and roast. Nice. Flavor is more the same. Plenty of chocolates and coffee with a sweet caramel, hazelnut creamer, brown sugar, vanilla, and roast before this completely dries with a light bitterness and lots of dry coffee and chocolate. Lengthy aftertaste after a medium to full body and light carbonation. A bit dusty in the finish with just a hint of alcohol warmth. Overall, a nice coffee stout. Lots of well balanced flavors and a nice, dry finish. Loads of chocolate keep the big amount of fresh, black coffee in check. Nice beer.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown color with a white head. The aroma is strong black coffee as well as chocolate. The flavor is more of the same with coffee dominating. Creamy, medium-thick mouthfeel and low-medium carbonation.

Remember, if she smokes, she pokes.. . aromas of hot coco, nawlins chocolate, and lots of dark roasted malts, also some light espresso .. . you wanna pick me up? .. . black as the night, with a very healthy head and nice lacing .. . medium thickness, warms the throat slightly .. not awfully complex when you microscope it but does contain some nice flavours of chocolate and roasted malt. .. i swear that nerf football was talking to me..

Pours deep brown/black with thin off white head, aroma is big coffee grounds, roast.  Taste is big coffee with a balanced chocolate taste finishing a bit dry and coffee flavored.  This would be amazing in the morning, one of the best coffee stouts ive ever had, rivaling surly!
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  The smell is oats, coffee, roasty, malts, and fresh ground coffee.  The look is black with a tan head.  The taste is malts, roasty, coffee, and chocolate.

Aroma is seriously coffee-like, bringing to mind a high-quality cup of joe. It pours a deep, rich, warm coffee brown that is nearly opaque and has a nice tan head. Rich coffee dominates the mouth-filling flavor as it does the aroma, and there is an undertone of unsweetened chocolate, so drinking this coffee is like more like drinking some cold quality mocha than drinking beer - and I love mocha. The smooth, lively, fizzy texture assures you that this is indeed beer, and a very good one at that. Recommended to all stout fans, especially if they love good coffee as well.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear brown body with a small light brown head that ran to a wispy film.  The nose is just wonderful to me, tons of day-old cold coffee over roast and some slight earthiness.  The flavor is just how I like it too, almost more coffee-like than beer.  On the sweeter side with some light malt and coffee derived bitterness on the finish.  Nice long lingering coffee finish.  Medium bodied with light soft carbonation, some slight clinginess on the back end.  Overall a pretty nice beer.  One that hits on some of my favorite notes at least.

A: The pour is black and somewhat viscous into my snifter with only a thin ring of tan foam.

S: The nose is pretty much all coffee. Theres a bit of chocolate and roasted malt, but these are definitely secondary to the coffee.

T: Like the nose, this one is coffee forward all the way. Plenty of coffee on the front end with a bit of roasted malt in the middle, along with an ever so slight sweetness of chocolate. The finish is even more coffee along with a slight bitterness.

M: The beer has a medium body with a low to moderate level of carbonation.

D: I have no idea what the ABV is on this one, but the booze certainly doesnt show up in the flavor. And the fact that its pretty much like drinking a cup of coffee makes this one easy drinking beer.

Nose is full of nice fresh coffee with some chocolate and dark malty notes as well. Pours dark brown with not much in the head department. Lighter brown hues. Coffee, caramel malts, chocolate, dark malts, roast, lingering fresh coffee flavors. Nice long lingering dry coffee mouth feel with soft earthy bitterness. On the lighter side of body, well carbonated. Nice.
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  Deep chocolate brown with a cream head.  Nose is coffee, light caramel, and more coffee.  Nice on the palate with flavors of coffee beans and caramel.

Whoaaa, Nelly Bell! This is one serious ass beer. The coffee qualities are at first so fresh and aromatic. Served with a fine, light tan nice head and some lace. Color is an opaque very dark brown or black. Aroma is totally dominated by the very fresh cofffee. Actually, in the aroma theres not a whole lot of beer character. Flavors where it all comes together. Solidly. Theres some dark ripe fruit, a little cocoa, some of the malt, hints of caramel, vanilla, roastiness, and toffee. Theres a short period of a bittersweetness and then fades to slightly dry. No alcohol at all. Session beer if youre into coffee stouts.
Bottle thanks to Cavie. Nose is chocolate frosted jalepeno studded cornbread. I dont know if such a product exists but I think it could be delightful. Taste is buttered chocolate powder. Well then.
( 12oz bottle thanks to cavie) Pours clear medium brown with great lacing. Nose of bread, sweet cracker, light cream coffee. Taste of coffee, sweet chocolate with a creamy finish.
Bottle thanks to cavie. Hazy dark brown pour. Aroma is coffee, unsweet chocolate and a bit of jalapeno. Flavor is spicy, coffee. Messy.

Bottle courtesy of bonk0076. Murky brown maroon color. Smells of sweet coffee, roasted malts and bitter elements. Flavorfully smooth with dark malts, roasted notes and lovely coffee. Well done, this is very good!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2010 12oz bottle courtesy of cavie.  Dark brown body with tan highlights and a small tan head.  Nose is malt sweet, hint of alcohol, freshly roasted coffee and tiny bit of bourbon(?).  Flavor follows the nose:  semi-sweet chocolate, fresh/light coffee, medium chocolate malt sweetness.  Very smooth coffee presence.  Excellent lingering mild coffee bitter finish.  Medium body and mouthfeel.

Bottle thanks to cavie. Pours with a suspiciously light brown body and a fading white head. Aroma of brown sugar, coffee, spice and light creamer. Taste is coffee and vanilla. Creamy with light bubbles.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of Skyview. Thanks! Pours a nearly opaque black with a medium tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is beautiful... rich coffee, sweet malts with a good bit of roastiness, and chocolate. Taste is bitter roasted malts and bitter coffee with caramel and some bitter hops in the finish. Medium bodied, fairly bitter but smooth. Lots of real coffee character. A good coffee stout. Well done.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 Bottle at Borefts 10am day after hotel tasting after a very bad drunk Borefts festival ... black ... huge soft coffee roast nose ... soft rich ... sweet soft roast ... loads of coffee ... very smooth ... very rich...

 remains of bottle 2 days later  in Hotel room in Amsterdam ... to make room in luggage ... deep black ... soft coffee roast nose ... deep deep coffee ... low bitterness ... rich and heavy ... little charcoal in linger ... 


Mixed with cuvve 2 barley wine ... lovely ... this tones down the coffee and bit and adds nice vanilla ... nice fruit with a coffee hit still there.

Cloudy dark brown with a thin tan head, slowly fading.  Aroma of heavy dark coffee, roasted malt and some chocolate.  Taste is very acidic with coffee, roasted malt, some sweetness and chocolate.  Mild bitter finish.  Just too acidic.

Bottle courtesy of furley from TBS.  Pitch black pour with a frothy brown head.  Smell is coffee bean, strong coffee.  Taste is similar, black coffee up front with a slightly sweeter finish.  Maybe some caramel in the finish?  Definite coffee taste all the way through.  Its slightly thinner than I was hoping for, in terms of mouthfeel.

In the bottle from a restaurant bottle shop in New Holland Michigan. Black as the Ace of Spades. Virtually no head whatsoever. Big roasted coffee aroma. The body is fairly thick with a massive coffee flavor. Importantly, it has a strong finish of acrolein. Burnt coffee, perhaps, but I mostly get pyrolyzed cigarettes. Has a really good milky malty sweet flavor not unlike what youd expect from a Baltic.

12 oz. pours jet black with bright caramel edges. light slim tan head. powerful coffee nose, very bright and roasty. creamy medium body with active carb and nice dimension. coffee, roasty mid palate with bits of malt sugar and some char. long roasty finish.

A Mes rate. Bottle at Borefts 10am day after hotel tasting.Fully black with a good beige head. Lashings of chocolate, roasted coffee and a really good smoky character. Dark chocolate bitterness in the finish rounds it off well. Straight down the line but very good indeed.

bottle courtesy of tytoanderso, thanks a lot! this is amazing! pours a thick medium/dark brown with a very dense brown head. smell is great, tons of coffee, tons of doughy yeast, roasty malts.  the flavor is full of win and wow!!! tons of coffee, and we are talking real, dark, roasty coffe, and a lot of it! one of the best coffe flavors ive had in any stout, imperial or otherwise!  mouthfeel is super cremy, then goes to a bitter, drying aspect like very strong, blck cowboy coffee. not folgers, french press blackness here, i really appreciate this brew and want more!

Pour is dark brown with a light brown head.  Aroma is notable coffee, light malt, and thats a bout it.  Flavor is heavy coffee, light malt, and faint molasses. It is a bit one dimensional, but still pretty good.
If coffee always tasted this good, Id drink it more often. This is a very good tasting and smooth stout from a great brewery.

Bottle 22fl.oz. @ post Borefts BF 09 hotel tastingClear dark brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, beige head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, moderate to heavy coffee, used coffee, coffee dusty. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20091031]

Bottle - Pours deep and dark, wtih a tan head that goes away real quick. Smell is a blast of wonderful coffee, chocolate, slight booze, and a little milkiness. Taste is sweet up front, then transitions into dark roast coffee, tar, charcoal, roasty malt, chocolate, and cinnamon. Its way smooth and feels good as it makes its way through the mouth. Theres a bit too much carbonation, but this is a nit. I like the way Central Waters does big beers, and this is no exception. Superb.

Brewed in the USA... Courtesy of FooFaa, thanks Dan !!! Pours dark brown in color with zero head. Aroma of smoke, roasted malts and coffee. Taste is much of the same !!! However, the coffee was not robust, its kind of bland overall. Mouthfeel is medium in body with some dry bitterness at the finish.

Bottle shared by Dan (FooFaa) at the Beer Advocate - Brass Rail tasting. Poured clear brown with a small tan head. The smell was dominated by coffee both freshly roasted and freshly brewed with some other roasted notes in the background. I was disappointed the into find out that those fresh coffee notes didnt carry over properly into the flavor of the beer. Instead the coffee tasted sour and stale like a late night cup of joe at Dennys.
POurs deep brown. Nose is fresh brewed coffee, roasty malt.Flavor is roasted grain, dark malts, bitter coffee, cocoa. Pretty decent coffee stout.

the pour is nearly black with a creamy tan head.  aroma is of mocha and strong dark coffee.  bittersweet chocolate, roasted malts and coffee dominate the flavor profile with a little spice on the tail end.  mouthfeel is creamy smooth and leaves a bit of sticky sweetness on the lips.  very nice!
12 oz. bottle from Casanova.  Dark brown pour, pillowy tan head.  Beautiful lacing.  Faint coffee grounds aroma.  Medium mouth feel, sharp coffee flavor with a bit of a sweet finish.

Bottle thanks to Barrythebear(BA)!Red-brown with an ample beige head. Nose heavily roasted, almost burnt. Similarly roasted flavor, light milk chocolate as balance. Moderate finish, more burnt elements clinging through the flavor. Pretty straightforward stuff, not entirely pleasing.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2009 GABF 2009, then again in a bottle received in a trade.  Darkest brown in color, damn near black, with a lasting tan head.  Aroma is loads of fresh-brewed coffee, roast, chocolate, and hops.  Flavor is roasted and caramel malt, slightly sweet, with great high-quality coffee, dark chocolate, and a hoppy kick.  Very well-balanced and not overwhelming on the coffee in the least.  Body is medium and a palate is fairly smooth, just a tiny bit astringent from the coffee, but really not to a fault.  Excellent stout overall.

Bottle  Pours a deep brown that looks black until studied closer.  Aroma is dark roast coffee, chocolate, roast, and some earthy notes. Flavor is malty, caramel, chocolate, roast, and bitter coffee.  Very solid beer that uses all the flavors well together.

12oz bottle courtesy of Skyview.  Pours a deep oxblood reddish brown with a thick 2 finger light tan head that leaves delicate lacing.  The nose is spent coffee grounds, dark chocolate and roasted malt.  The taste is chocolate, medium roast coffee and ashy malt.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Good stout.  Thanks Bob!

Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, carmel, light vanilla and light roastiness. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark chocolate, coffee, roastiness, light vanilla and a hint of licorice with a smooth dry lingering roasty coffee finish.

Bottle courtesy of shawnm213.  Pours dark brown with a generous tan head.  Smells of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, peppery.  Tastes of roasted malt, peppery, complimentary coffee beans, some bitter hints.  Enjoyable!

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2010 Poured dark brown with thick tan head with aromas of coffee followed by dark chocolates,vanilla and roasted malts taste is dominated by coffee with chocolate and vanilla under tones finish is of slightly bitter coffee is long and abrupt, it is quite amazing and would love to compare it to bells java stout side by side some brewers cn do a great coffee stout and some cant

another excellent addition to the coffee stout genre.  pours very dark brown with small tan heads that fades rather quickly.  nose is mild coffee and a tinge of molasses with a bit of smoked wood.  taste is medium coffee and a bit of roasted chocolate and malty goodness.  a very, very good beer that i really wish they would sell in minnesota so i could save me from driving to hudson whenever im hankering for the hunkering.

Good dark color though non-opaque brown (could be richer).  Aroma of coffee grounds.  Good rich flavor and long finish.  The brewery had the smell of cow barn, which made it a bit difficult to sort out the aromas at first, but once this warmed a bit (served too cold) it reached a delightful flavor and palate.  On tap at brewery bar.

Cheers Mike for sharing this one.
Pours clear brown, off white head.
Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and some bready notes.Flavor, malty, followed by decent amount of coffee goodness.
Coffee is all over this one though not adding much bitterness as some coffee tend to do. There is still some bitter elements in the finish but this one is just another home-run for CW.
Simple yet well crafted beer.
Aroma is of coffee.  Flavor is a coffee explosion in the mouth with roasted malt and some sweets.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2009 Central Waters is NEVER dissapointing.  Any one who thinks guinness tastes like coffee (I think its remarkably like water) should stay far away from this beer.  Ive had 3 or 4 coffees and this is the one that tastes the BEST!!!

Bottle shared by StFun. Pours opaque with a brown head and plenty of floaties. He nose is just a big slap in the face with some good coffee. The coffee flavor is less bold, but thats good. Some good roasty flavors and mild bitterness. Medium-light body and really dry. I good pound this one for hours.
Bottle. Aroma of fresh, pretty heavily roasted, Columbian coffee. Flavor more coffee with roasted malt notes and sweet, milky touches. Great coffee presence with the beer to back it up. Nice stuff.
Awesome beer.  Very smooth a choclately.  Medium body.  A lot of flavor, creamy mouthfeel.  Roasty, a little toasty.  Worth drinking.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2009 22oz bomber.  Opaque brown-black color with a whole lot of floaties.  Big luscious tan head.  Smooth chocolate coffee aroma with some alcohol warmth.  Mystery ABV sort of makes this a hard one to judge.  Some upfront hop and cocoa bitterness lead to a thick sandy chocolate mocha smooth sweet finish.  I would guess A decently high ABV, probably not higher than 8, and not under 6.  Big, thick, rich coffee flavor.  A respectable beer for sure, pretty intense.

Sampled at GTMW 2009.  Pours dark with a creamy off-white head.  Rich coffee aroma.  Very good flavor of, you guessed it, coffee.  Thin bodied but rich in flavor.  There are some great, flavorful coffee Imperial Stouts out there but rarely do you find such a flavorful coffee stout.  Very good.

22oz bomber
Pours a dark chestnut-brown with strange fizzy bubbly head -- kind of looks like cola thats starting to go flat. Aroma is coffee accented by a pungent, peppery spice. Flavor is much the same -- coffee with chocolate notes and a spicy, peppery kick, but the pepper is dialed down compared to the aroma (thankfully). Palate is thinnish and oily.  Tastes like a milder and better-crafted version of Vikings Hot Chocolate, which isnt necessarily a bad thing, but I wasnt quite prepared for it.

Thanks to alcstradamus for this one.  Another outstanding CW beer.  Pours dark brown with soapy tan head.  Nose is a ton of roast, lots of chicory, earth, spice, and more coffee.  Cracking this beer smells like walking into Barnies. Flavor is roast, earth, fresh exotic coffee, Medium to full-bodied with finish of sweet black coffee.  Outstanding coffee beer.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2009 Bottle courtesy of markwise, Pours a dark brown to black with thin tan head. Aroma is sweet and roasty with notes of coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, some hints of caramel and honey. Flavor is sweet and roasted with notes of espresso coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, hints of molasses and caramel. Generally medium body with a pleasing roasted finish.
From the bottle, pours black with a lasting tan head.  Aroma and taste are strongly coffee/espresso, with dark roasted malts mixed in as well.  Thick but not chewy and pretty good.
This poured a dark brown color. It smells like old coffe and tastes like coffee grounds. A bitter finish. Overall this was ok.

Courtesy SecretSanta. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a small tan head that settles to a thin film. The aroma is of fresh coffee grinds, chocolate and roasted malts, and a hint of cream. The flavor follows with bittersweet chocolate and coffee dominating. Medium bodied and fairly smooth with a roasty and bitter finish. Pretty nice coffee stout.

22 oz bomber courtesy of Todd.  Pours a chocolaty brown color with a medium sized light brown bordering on beige head.  Aroma of freshly brewed coffee,  vanilla cream, espresso and nuts.  Taste of coffee, vanilla cream, chocolate and nuts.  Not bad.
